an4.45:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an4.45:4.2: Then, late at night, the beautiful god Rohitassa, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha,
an4.45:5.1: “Sir, is it possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by travelling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn?”
an4.45:5.2: “Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by travelling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.”
an4.45:6.2: how well said this was by the Buddha.
an4.45:7.1: Once upon a time, I was a seer called Rohitassa, son of Bhoja. I was a sky-walker with psychic powers.
an4.45:7.2: I was as fast as a light arrow easily shot across the shadow of a palm tree by a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow.
an4.45:7.3: My stride was such that it could span from the eastern ocean to the western ocean.
an4.45:7.4: Having such speed and stride, this wish came to me:
an4.45:7.5: ‘I will reach the end of the world by travelling.’
an4.45:7.6: I traveled for my whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—and I died along the way, never reaching the end of the world.
an4.45:8.2: how well said this was by the Buddha.”
an4.45:9.1: “Reverend, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by travelling to a place where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.
an4.45:9.2: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.
an4.45:9.3: For it is in this fathom-long carcass with its perception and mind that I describe the world, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.”

an4.45:11.1: So a clever person, understanding the world,
an4.45:11.2: has lived the spiritual life, and gone to the end of the world.
an4.45:11.3: A peaceful one, knowing the end of the world,
an4.45:11.4: does not hope for this world or the next.”
